item.title: From 'gajar ka halwa' to hormonal disruptions: How overindulgence in high-sugar desserts lead to health condi - Indiatimes.com
item.description:
The Health Risks of Overindulging in High-Sugar Desserts

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Indiatimes

As winter approaches, people crave traditional sweets like 'Gajar ka Halwa'. However, excessive consumption can lead to serious health issues such as obesity, diabetes, and hormonal imbalances.

  • High-sugar desserts can contribute to obesity and related health conditions.
  • Common ailments linked to overindulgence include diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular diseases.
  • Hormonal disruptions can occur due to excessive sugar intake, leading to issues like insulin resistance.
  • Dr. Aruna Mallya and Dr. Satish N highlight potential health risks, including premature childbirth and high cholesterol.
“Excess sugar consumption can lead to detrimental effects on one's health, more so because it causes weight gain and hormonal discrepancies.” - Dr. Satish N

With rising sweet consumption, awareness about its health impacts is crucial for better lifestyle choices.

item.title: 10 vegetarian ways to increase daily protein intake - Recipes
item.description:
10 Vegetarian Ways to Increase Daily Protein Intake

Date: Dec 30, 2024 | Source: Times of India

Protein is essential for muscle repair and general health, especially for vegans facing challenges in daily protein intake. This article discusses 10 vegetarian sources to help improve protein consumption.

  • Legumes: Includes lentils, chickpeas, and beans.
  • Tofu and Tempeh: Plant-based protein sources.
  • Quinoa: Complete protein with all essential amino acids.
  • Greek Yogurt: Higher protein content than regular yogurt.
  • Nuts and Seeds: Various options for snacks and smoothies.
  • Edamame: Young soybeans rich in protein and fiber.
  • Seitan: High-protein gluten product.
  • Paneer: Dairy product high in protein.
  • Spinach and Leafy Greens: Adding greens helps increase protein intake.
  • Plant-based Protein Powders: Easy supplements for protein needs.
“If you are having trouble meeting your protein needs, plant-based protein powders can be an easy and effective way to supplement your intake.”

Incorporating these vegetarian sources can significantly help in achieving daily protein goals.

item.title: Bilateral primary vitreoretinal lymphoma masquerading as fungal endophthalmitis- a case report - Journal of Ophthalmic Inflammation and Infection
item.description:
Bilateral Primary Vitreoretinal Lymphoma Masquerading as Fungal Endophthalmitis - A Case Report

Published: 30 December 2024 | Source: Journal of Ophthalmic Inflammation and Infection, Volume 14, Article number 69

This article reports a case of bilateral primary vitreoretinal lymphoma (PVRL) that was initially suspected to be an infectious endophthalmitis in a patient with recent cataract surgery and COVID-19 history. The diagnosis was eventually confirmed through multimodal imaging and a sub retinal biopsy.

  • A 60-year-old male patient presented with vision loss post cataract surgery.
  • Clinical suspicion of endophthalmitis led to diagnostic vitrectomy, which returned negative microbiological results.
  • Multimodal imaging and biopsy confirmed PVRL, which was treated with intravitreal methotrexate.
  • Patient achieved remission after multiple injections.
“Vitritis with sub-RPE yellowish deposits may be mistaken for infectious endophthalmitis, especially in a patient with a history of intraocular surgery or immunosuppression.”

This case emphasizes the importance of considering PVRL in differential diagnosis, especially for middle-aged patients presenting with similar symptoms, highlighting how critical timely diagnosis and appropriate management can be for patient outcomes.

item.title: Malaysian diabetics face medicine shortage as slimming craze thins supply of Ozempic - asianews.network
item.description:
Ozempic Shortage in Malaysia: Slimming Craze Impacts Diabetics

Date & Source: December 30, 2024, PETALING JAYA

Malaysian Pharmacists Society president Amrahi Buang confirmed the shortage of Ozempic, a diabetes medication that has gained popularity as a weight-loss solution. The increased demand from non-diabetic individuals has led to a scarcity, impacting those who genuinely need the drug to manage their diabetes.

  1. Ozempic, a semaglutide injectable medication, helps manage blood sugar levels in adults with Type 2 diabetes.
  2. Pharmacists warn against misusing the drug for weight loss without medical supervision due to potential side effects like hypoglycemia.
  3. Distributors have started rationing supplies to ensure broader access.
  4. Side effects include nausea, diarrhoea, constipation, and vomiting, with potential long-term effects like gallbladder issues.
  5. Semaglutide should be used alongside lifestyle and dietary changes, with serious complications like pancreatitis being rare.
“There are many who are interested only in the drug’s weight loss potency, creating a huge demand and a shortage in the market.” – Amrahi Buang, Malaysian Pharmacists Society president

Conclusion: The global weight loss craze around Ozempic has led to a shortage in Malaysia, impacting diabetics who rely on the medication to manage their blood sugar levels. Pharmacists and medical professionals warn against misusing the drug without proper medical guidance.

item.title: CDC Detects Bird Flu Mutation in Human, Amid New Infections in Cats - ScienceAlert
item.description:
CDC Detects Bird Flu Mutation in Human, Amid New Infections in Cats

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: Agence France-Presse

The ongoing spread of bird flu in the United States has alarmed experts, especially with new infections reported in cats and a potential mutation of the virus in humans.

  • A sample from a critically ill patient in Louisiana shows signs of mutation that may enhance the virus's ability to infect humans.
  • The CDC reported 65 confirmed human cases of bird flu in 2024, with more potentially undetected.
  • An infected cat in Oregon died from contaminated raw pet food, raising concerns over transmission risks to humans.
  • The mutation in the human virus is believed to have occurred during replication in the ill patient, with no evidence of wider human transmission.
  • Experts caution that while mutations can help virus binding, they do not necessarily indicate increased transmissibility or severity.
"It's good to know we should be looking out for this, but it doesn't actually tell us, 'Oh, we're this much closer to a pandemic now.'" — Dr. Angela Rasmussen

Researchers are also monitoring infections in cats, as this could pose a risk for human transmission. Prompt attention is necessary to understand the implications of these developments.

item.title: Vaccines to be made available on Wednesdays at wellness centres in TN - DTNEXT
item.description:
Vaccines to be Available Every Wednesday at Wellness Centres in Tamil Nadu

Date: Recent
Source: Directorate of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

The Directorate of Public Health has mandated that all Health and Wellness Centres in Tamil Nadu will offer vaccines every Wednesday, aiming to enhance immunisation services in urban regions.

  • Vaccines provided under the Universal Immunization Programme cover 12 Vaccine Preventable Diseases.
  • Annually, approximately 9.57 lakh pregnant women and 8.77 lakh children are immunised through this initiative.
  • There are 2,712 Cold Chain Points across the state to store vaccines.
  • Immunisation is part of a comprehensive service package provided at these centres.
  • The initiative aims to address gaps in vaccine coverage in urban areas.
“A shortfall of routine immunisation doses has been observed against the targeted number.”

To enhance routine immunisation and combat vaccine-preventable diseases, all district health officers are directed to integrate 708 HWCs into their immunisation plans.

item.title: Ozone therapy promising new treatment for sepsis-induced lung injury: Study - Nagaland Post
item.description:
Ozone therapy promising new treatment for sepsis-induced lung injury: Study

Publication Date: [Insert publication date here] | Source: Nagaland Post

This study from Nanjing Medical University highlights ozone therapy as a hopeful new treatment for sepsis-induced acute lung injury (ALI).

  • Sepsis is a severe complication of infection and a leading cause of ALI and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • Medical ozone therapy showed potential to improve survival rates in preclinical models of sepsis-induced ALI.
  • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs), which trap pathogens, can also trigger inflammation, worsening lung injury.
  • The study discusses the mechanisms by which ozone therapy clears NETs and improves lung function.
  • Dr. Wen-Tao Liu noted that this therapy could lead to better outcomes for sepsis patients.
  • If validated in human trials, ozone therapy may become a significant treatment option.
  • The advancement of this therapy could reshape the management of sepsis, offering new hope for those affected.
“Our research demonstrates that medical ozone therapy could dramatically improve the management of sepsis-induced ALI.” - Dr. Wen-Tao Liu

This research marks a critical step in exploring innovative treatments for sepsis, aiming to enhance patient care in critical settings.

item.title: Who Is Leana Wen? Health Expert Slammed For Advocating Immediate H5N1 Vaccine Approval - Times Now
item.description:
Who Is Leana Wen? Health Expert Advocates for Quick H5N1 Vaccine Approval

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Times Now

Dr. Leana Wen, a prominent public health figure, urges the Biden administration to expedite the approval and rollout of H5N1 bird flu vaccines amidst growing concerns about potential outbreaks.

  • Wen emphasizes the availability of an H5N1 vaccine, noting that the administration has contracted for nearly 5 million doses.
  • She highlights the need for rapid testing for farm workers and their families to identify potential viral risks.
  • Wen expresses worries about policy shifts under a new administration and advocates for transparency in reporting bird flu cases.
  • Advises that caution against the consequences of delayed vaccine authorization could mirror early COVID-19 challenges.
This is not like the early days of COVID. We have a vaccine for H5N1. The Biden administration has already contracted for nearly 5 million doses.

In conclusion, Dr. Wen calls for immediate action to prevent potential health crises, stressing the importance of being prepared and proactive in healthcare strategies.

item.title: Over 14k cases dog bite cases till Nov in Madurai - The Times of India
item.description:
Over 14,000 Dog Bite Cases Reported in Madurai This Year

Publication Date: November 2023 | Source: Times of India

This article reports that Madurai has seen over 14,000 dog bite cases up to November 2023, raising concerns about public safety and animal control.

  • The cases have been steadily increasing throughout the year.
  • Local authorities are being urged to take appropriate measures to address the issue.
  • Public health officials emphasize the importance of proper vaccinations for pets.
“The rise in dog bite cases is alarming and requires immediate action from the government,” said a local health official.

As the dog bite cases continue to grow, stakeholders are pressured to implement effective animal control measures and educate the public.

item.title: ‘1 in 7 mentally ill. Globally, 1 in 8’ - The Times of India
item.description:
1 in 7 Mentally Ill. Globally, 1 in 8

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

This article discusses the alarming mental health statistics indicating that 1 in 7 individuals worldwide suffer from mental illness, with a focus on the growing need for awareness and resources to address this crisis.

  • 1 in 7 people are affected by mental health issues globally.
  • This statistic highlights the significant prevalence of mental illness across different regions.
  • Calls for improved mental health services and support systems are emphasized.
  • The importance of societal awareness and education on mental health challenges is discussed.
“Addressing mental health is crucial for the overall well-being of society.”

This article sheds light on the pressing issue of mental health and advocates for greater understanding and resources dedicated to mental health support globally.

item.title: Not all high-protein foods are good for your health: Here's what to know - The Times of India
item.description:
Not all high-protein foods are good for your health: Here's what to know

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

With a growing focus on fitness and wellness, many food products claim to be healthy. A study from Spain published in Nutrients reveals that not all high-protein foods are beneficial for health, often containing high levels of sodium and fats.

  • A study evaluated over 4,000 processed high-protein food products.
  • Many claimed high protein content but were found to have unhealthy ingredients like added sugars and saturated fats.
  • Over 90% of these foods were concluded to be less healthy due to added fats and sweeteners.
  • Real high-protein sources include fish, meat, eggs, and dairy, alongside vegan options like soy and lentils.
“The assumption of high protein food might not always be healthy.”

People are cautioned against relying on processed 'high-protein' foods, suggesting to focus on natural sources instead.

item.title: Not all packaged food labels have complete information! - ఇండియా హెరాల్డ్ గ్రూప్ అఫ్ పబ్లిషర్స్ ప్రై లిమిటెడ్ - India Herald Group of Publishers P LIMITED
item.description:
Not all packaged food labels have complete information!

Date & Source: October 2023, Source Not Specified

This article discusses the lack of complete nutritional information on packaged food labels, highlighting misleading health claims and the need for clearer labeling systems to help consumers make healthier choices.

  • Some packaged foods, such as raw agricultural products, do not need to provide nutritional information.
  • Health claims can be misleading, making unhealthy processed foods appear healthy.
  • A study by the FSSAI revealed that essential nutritional information is often lacking on food labels.
  • Only certain breakfast cereals and beverages provided portion information.
  • Misleading claims about whole grains can confuse customers due to incomplete ingredient lists.
  • There's been a rise in spending on packaged foods among Indians, contributing to health issues like obesity and diabetes.
  • Bad eating habits account for 56.4% of diseases in India, according to a recent survey.
“Experts say that this change in eating habits is a major reason for the increasing burden of obesity, diabetes, heart attack in the country.”

Clear labeling is essential for enabling customers to make informed choices about their food, particularly as lifestyles shift towards convenience over health.

item.title: Health threat! Is packaged food really healthy? - ఇండియా హెరాల్డ్ గ్రూప్ అఫ్ పబ్లిషర్స్ ప్రై లిమిటెడ్ - India Herald Group of Publishers P LIMITED
item.description:
Health threat! Is packaged food really healthy?

Date: October 2023 | Source: India Herald

Indians' food preferences are shifting from raw vegetables and whole grains to packaged and processed foods. A recent study published in Plos One examines the health implications of this trend by analyzing the nutritional labels of packaged foods in the Indian market.

  • The study involved experts from Madras Diabetes Research Foundation, Medical Research Council of India, and the University of Reading, England.
  • Researchers analyzed 432 different packaged foods, including breakfast cereals and snacks.
  • Results showed that 80% of the nutritional information on the labels was accurate.
  • High levels of carbohydrates in these foods can lead to health issues like obesity and heart disease if consumed excessively.
  • Excess fat consumption, particularly from puffed snacks, can increase cholesterol levels and heart disease risk.
“Excess carbohydrates can cause obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. High fat content can increase cholesterol and heart disease risk.”

This research highlights the importance of understanding packaged food labels and their health implications in the context of changing dietary habits among Indians.

item.title: Mpox Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries That Recorded Mpox Cases This Year - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Mpox Outbreak Of 2024: A Global Review Of Countries That Recorded Mpox Cases This Year

Publication Date: 2024-08-14 Source: The Health Site

The mpox disease has been declared a public health emergency of international concern by WHO, stemming from significant outbreaks primarily in Africa but now spreading to non-African countries.

African Countries Reporting Mpox Cases in 2024

  1. Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC): 6,169 confirmed cases, 25 deaths.
  2. Burundi: 2,650 confirmed cases, 1 death.
  3. Nigeria: 94 confirmed cases, no deaths.
  4. Uganda: 1,027 confirmed cases, 6 deaths.
  5. Central African Republic: 263 confirmed cases, 28 deaths.
  6. Cameroon: 35 confirmed cases, 2 deaths.
  7. Ivory Coast: 28 confirmed cases, 1 death.
  8. Republic of Congo: 158 confirmed cases, 21 deaths.
  9. Ghana: 2 confirmed cases, no deaths.
  10. Kenya: 29 confirmed cases, 1 death.
  11. South Africa: 24 confirmed cases, 3 deaths.
  12. Rwanda: 59 confirmed cases, no deaths.
  13. Zambia: At least 1 confirmed case.
  14. Mozambique: At least 1 confirmed case.

Non-African Countries Reporting Mpox Cases in 2024

  1. United Kingdom: At least 5 confirmed cases (some linked to travel).
  2. Canada: At least 1 confirmed case.
  3. Belgium: At least 1 confirmed case.
  4. Sweden: At least 1 confirmed case.
  5. Germany: At least 1 confirmed case.
  6. Oman: At least 1 confirmed case.
  7. India: At least 1 confirmed case.
  8. Pakistan: At least 1 confirmed case.
  9. Thailand: At least 1 confirmed case.
  10. United States of America: At least 1 confirmed case (linked to traveler from Africa).

The spread of mpox is a growing concern globally, with the DRC remaining the most affected country. The WHO continues to classify mpox as a public health emergency, emphasizing the importance of vigilance and precautionary measures.

item.title: Concerns expressed over rising autism, cancer, and degenerative diseases due to presence of toxins in environment - The Hindu
item.description:
Concerns Over Rising Autism, Cancer, and Degenerative Diseases Linked to Environmental Toxins

Date: December 29, 2024 Source: The Hindu

Experts raised concerns over the increasing incidence of illnesses such as autism and cancer linked to environmental toxins at an international symposium.

  • A diverse group of medical professionals discussed the role of heavy metals, pollution, and pesticides in health crises.
  • Praveen Saxena emphasized the importance of understanding toxin impacts for better medical care.
  • The symposium called for collaborative efforts to address the challenges posed by environmental toxins.
  • Other speakers discussed personalized treatment approaches and the interplay of cancer with environmental factors.
  • Dr. Narasimha Reddy Donthi highlighted the impact of pesticides on health.
  • Various treatment strategies, including ozone therapy and early detection, were advised for combatting cancer.
“Cancer is a manifestation rather than a disease,” said one expert at the symposium.

The symposium underscored the need for a holistic and integrative approach to healthcare to effectively address the rising health concerns linked to environmental toxins.

item.title: Do all pets need a rabies vaccine? We ask the experts - The Indian Express
item.description:
Do all pets need a rabies vaccine? We ask the experts

Publication Date: October 2023, Source: Indian Express

Rabies is a fatal viral disease affecting mammals and can be prevented through vaccination. Experts emphasize the necessity of rabies vaccination for pets, particularly dogs, cats, and ferrets.

  • All dogs, cats, and ferrets should be vaccinated for rabies.
  • Small mammals, reptiles, amphibians, birds, and fish do not require rabies vaccination.
  • Vaccination helps prevent the disease and protects public health.
  • Initial vaccination typically occurs at 12-16 weeks of age.
  • Booster shots are needed every 1-3 years, based on the vaccine type.
“Rabies is a fatal viral disease that affects the nervous system of mammals, including humans. It is primarily spread through the bite of an infected animal and vaccination is the most effective way to prevent rabies in pets and protect human health.” - Dr. Ishan, Petcare Pro Clinic

Vaccination is essential to prevent rabies transmission and has public health implications.
